<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 202]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 259]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/31 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 359, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 904, 317]]<|/det|> October/November 2021 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 904, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 890, 606]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 220, 650]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 651, 730, 683]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 720, 905, 850]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 867, 727, 884]]<|/det|> This document has 16 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 737, 89]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 534, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 133, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
Slide the loop of a spring onto a wooden rod. Fix the loop of the spring in the middle of the wooden rod with a clip, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 175, 764, 307]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 320, 533, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 178, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 352, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
Use half of the adhesive putty to fix four \(10\mathrm{g}\) masses to the wooden rod as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 393, 804, 567]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 581, 534, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 178, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 613, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
Adjust the positions of the masses until the distance between the masses is approximately \(22 \text{cm}\). The masses should each be approximately the same distance from the clip, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 178, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 801, 89]]<|/det|>
Clamp the loop at the top of the spring between two small wooden blocks.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 180, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 556, 121]]<|/det|>
Arrange the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 128, 839, 440]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 450, 534, 469]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 482, 178, 500]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 481, 913, 500]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of the clip until the rod balances approximately parallel to the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 175, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 513, 851, 532]]<|/det|>
The distance between the masses on the wooden rod is \(x\), as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 545, 384, 562]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 605, 920, 623]]<|/det|>
<form>\(x =\)  ...............................................  [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 636, 146, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 636, 880, 655]]<|/det|>
Using the other wooden rod, set up a second set of apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 668, 180, 686]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 667, 680, 686]]<|/det|>
The distance between the masses on this wooden rod is \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 698, 823, 717]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of the masses until the value of \(p\) is approximately \(18 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 731, 178, 748]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 730, 384, 748]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 790, 920, 809]]<|/det|>
<form>\(p =\)  ....................................................  [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 72, 168, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Move the apparatus until the two rods are close to each other and in line as shown in Fig. 1.4.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[62, 114, 935, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 286, 534, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 318, 185, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 318, 591, 337]]<|/det|>
Gently press the rods down at end X and end P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 180, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 850, 369]]<|/det|>
Release the ends at the same time. The ends will oscillate as shown in Fig. 1.5.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 375, 917, 504]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 516, 534, 535]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 180, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 549, 670, 567]]<|/det|>
Watch the oscillations. X and P move in and out of phase.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 581, 176, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 580, 920, 615]]<|/det|>
Look at P. Count the number \(n\) of oscillations made by P from release until both ends are back in phase.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 687, 920, 705]]<|/det|>
<form>n = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
Change \(p\) in the range \(14.0 \text{cm} \leqslant p \leqslant 20.5 \text{cm}\) and repeat **(c)** until you have six sets of values of \(p\) and \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 388, 137]]<|/det|>
**Keep distance** \(\mathbf{x}\) **constant.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 144, 728, 173]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{1}{p}\) and \(\frac{1}{n}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 175, 567, 203]]<|/det|>
Record the values of \(\frac{1}{n}\) to three significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 523, 920, 542]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 143, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 554, 176, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 551, 640, 579]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{n}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{p}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 555, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 585, 180, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 584, 457, 603]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 585, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 616, 180, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 616, 608, 635]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 836, 917, 856]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 867, 917, 886]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 883, 920, 902]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 635, 89]]<|/det|>
Draw a circle of radius 2.0 cm on the blank sheet of paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 181, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 650, 121]]<|/det|>
● Place a Petri dish on top of the circle on the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 218, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 134, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
Use small pieces of adhesive putty at the edge of the Petri dish to secure it to the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 218, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 180, 789, 199]]<|/det|>
Place a small piece of adhesive putty at the centre of the Petri dish.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 212, 218, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 212, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
Gently press the straw into the adhesive putty so that the bottom of the straw is sealed by the putty.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 259, 218, 277]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 259, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Arrange the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.2 and Fig. 2.3 with the straw above the centre of the circle drawn on the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 303, 318, 320]]<|/det|>
TOP VIEW

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 330, 863, 560]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 572, 534, 590]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 602, 270, 619]]<|/det|>
SIDE VIEW

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 813, 534, 831]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 213, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 839, 89]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with plastic gloves to wear when handling the oil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 102, 559, 120]]<|/det|>
Use the dropper to fill the straw with oil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 212, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 134, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
When the straw is lifted from the putty, the oil spreads out. The time taken for the first part of the oil to reach the circle is \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 180, 564, 198]]<|/det|>
Gently lift the straw away from the putty.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 212, 212, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 212, 418, 230]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 335, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
<form>t = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 365, 183, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 365, 808, 384]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(t\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 535, 146, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 535, 603, 554]]<|/det|>
Repeat (a)(i), (a)(iii) and (b)(i) using the longer straw.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 618, 918, 636]]<|/det|>
<form>l = ...............................................................

<form>t = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 604, 90]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(V\) and \(t\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[468, 102, 531, 131]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{k}{\sqrt{t}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 139, 339, 158]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 170, 181, 189]]<|/det|>
